paragraphs.text: Anyway, thanks for writing and sharing this amazing story, it changed our view on Chinese tourists :)

Parisians, Vancouverites, and San Franciscans may feel similarly. But Louis Vitton, Gucci and Apple (AAPL: 143.34) don’t seem to care. I’ve talked to many local businesses all over the world who complain about the Chinese, but who readily accept their cash.

576fe93215d6.name: Welcom' to Paris
576fe93215d6.bio: Helping travellers to meet Parisians and experience the real Paris with them. Join us : www.welcom.city

ae72b162da0c.name: Utsav Mamoria
ae72b162da0c.bio: Researcher at heart, loves to understand human behaviour, author of upcoming book: China Unseen — https://www.facebook.com/ChinaUnseen/

2a4d8adfaaaa.name: Kaizhi Meng
2a4d8adfaaaa.bio: Computer Engineering Student, Formula 1 Lover, Windows Phone/ Windows 8 developer, tech-journalist-to-be

paragraphs.text: No, it isn’t. Definitely goes both ways. Which is why I think it’s so important for an insular, 92% ethnically homogenous nation like China to have it’s people travel outside its own borders, even if in large packs.

As someone who lived in China and has seen these groups in China as well, I completely agree with you that we need to see the Chinese in context of their recent history and the times they grew up in. Living through the Great Depression and Cultural Revolution would irrevocably change anyone. We are all people shaped by our…

paragraphs.text: I do wonder what the reaction would be if this was written from the perspective of a white person. “Oh you should excuse them when they break local customs, offend people, are rude and entitled; it is just what they are used to at home.” Would that fly?

paragraphs.text: Lovely. Thank you for sharing.

I also wonder the same things. My intention is not to excuse poor behavior. My intention is to help increase understanding and perspective. Frankly, being someone who is often embarrassed by the poor behavior of some/many Chinese tour groups, this essay as more catharsis for myself in being less judgmental to my own people. Thanks for sharing your perspective, Michael.

(Other wimpier cultures — Americans, French, Germans — are only…

paragraphs.name: da3c
paragraphs.text: We can confess that in Paris, we don’t like tourists. Tourists in large groups, to be precise. But the fact is, we appreciate that they want to see our city, but they are a major problem : too many coaches inside our streets, we can’t access our museums and Grands Magasins anymore, and the worst is : they are only here to take pictures of all the…
